We take the kids here all the time. I love the flowers and trees.....the kids love the ice creams, ducks and swan. Every summer we dress the kids up and take some pics. Beautiful place to just sit and have a coffee.

this place is very nice if you are into flowers and gardens. you have to be there at a specific time of the year too when the flowers are blooming.. it is in the middle of the city so when you are looking for a quiet place to stroll , this is the place to go to.. they've maintained this...

Public gardens is the place to be in the spring,summer and fall. It's ideal for strolls, jogging, picnics, wedding pictures, prom pictures, graduation pictures, reading books, ect... Public gardens has an ice cream parlour and washroom faculties, you and your family are shore to enjoy this lovely park!

The gardens were opened in the mid-1800s, and we liked the huge wrought iron entrance gate. All of the flowers were in bloom and the ducks were swimming in the pond. What a perfect place to unwind after a busy day in the city!

The public gardens was a very nice stroll. My wife and I were doing a walking tour of Halifax and discovered this place. There were some nice areas to be seen. The weather wasn't the best but I was still able to get some very nice photos. Anybody looking for some free viewing this is the place.

If you are ever in Halifax during the summer I would highly recommend taking a visit to the Halifax Public Gardens. As long time residents of Nova Scotia my family and I have been annual visitors to the Gardens. Great for the little ones with lots of birds to chase. If it is a beautiful sunny weekend you can expect...
We visited on October 14th and expected it to be way past it's prime, however it was still in full bloom! Just beautiful and definitely worth a visit!!!
The color and cleanliness of this publc garden is remarkable. I was amazed to see the number of tropical plants and to find out they move them into greenhouses in winter

We walked to the gardens from the cruise ship pier. It is a bit up hill, but we got directions for a side approach that wasn't a bad climb. We strolled around and relaxed on a bench admiring the view. It also borders the fort on one side. Many of the specimens were labeled, which is always of interest to...

It was September, so we wondered if many flowers would be in bloom. Not to worry! Two dahlia gardens were trying to outdo each other - I took 31 pictures of varieties I would love to obtain! The day-care children and young mothers with strollers added to the charm, and showed how integral a part of the city the garden...

The place is wonderful. Great for strolling and relaxing. Beautifully landscaped and well planned distribution and arrangement of plants are perfect. All very clean and well organized, and safe. It has easy access to various points of entry and exit. I recommend to anyone who enjoys gardening or just want to get some rest in a place of beauty, peace...

We strolled through this absolutely beautiful garden filled with specimen perfect flowers and shrubs. It was spotlessly clean and cared for. Everywhere you look it is a photo opportunity. Lovely statues, fountains, arbors and streams all in picturesque settings. The entrance gates are nicely done and frame the landscape. Not to be missed when in the city!
I loved the old trees, the water falls, statues, friendly ducks, meandering paths, and the cozy place to buy some tea

We found the gardens to be everything we expected and so much more .Residents of the community were very helpful.The gardens reminded me of the Brooklyn Botanical Garden,that we spent many days at in our youth.I recommend that everyone vist.

Any person in Halifax should visit the Public Gardens at least once. The Victorian-style Gardens are beautiful, quiet, and best of all, free! It's nice that there are rules there too, like no smoking allowed, so everyone can equally enjoy their stroll.

Great way to spend a sunny afternoon. Whether you're into flowers/gardens or not you can't deny the beauty this park has to offer. It's also a free attraction if you happen to be travelling on a budget. Lots of photo ops, beautiful gazebo as the focal point and even saw a cormorant fishing for lunch in the pond.
i landed here one time. it was great. the air quality was superb. blah blah anyways if u like to goto canada this is a great place to be canadian. i like trees.

If you're at the Citadel, take the short walk over to the gardens and have your camera ready. The gardens are a lovely walk and worth the diversion. It was pouring rain when we were there and it still managed to be a lovely stop.
This is a lovely spot to stroll and enjoy nature for an hour or so in the midst of a busy day. It is right in the heart of downtown Halifax, near shopping, restaurants and movie theater.
Spent a few hours strolling through these Gardens. A simple, elegant, peaceful garden that has lots to see. Bring a few dollars to buy an ice cream or snack at the little stand near the gazebo.
very attractively planted and labeled. Quiet. Almost felt as if we were in our own, but enhanced garden. Take time to walk the entire area. Good and pleasant easy exercise'

We visited the gardens for a 20 minute stop on a 3 hour tour of Halifax. Could have spent more time here. Flowers everywhere, duck ponds, little waterfalls, nice benches to relax. Lots of picture taking. Altho we didn't see one on our visit, I can imagine that this would be a very popular place for weddings. I'm in California,...

Beautifully landscaped and scrupulously maintained, this is a lovely respite right in the city. The whole place is charming and rather nostalgic with the band shell in the middle and the cute little coffee shop serving papadoms of all things.

What a surprise! A lovely Victorian garden perfectly maintained. Even my husband who is not a garden person enjoyed it. Among the gardens was a wonderful dahlia display. Common Grounds had a shop in one of the houses and is a nice place for a croissant and coffee. I had a bagel and egg sandwich that was good. Beautiful Victorian...

My wife read that this was the finest Victorian garden on the east coast of Canada. We were not disappointed. It was a sunny day in October so the park was full of people (not crowded). We enjoyed walking around and enjoying all the beautiful gardens, ponds, trees, statues, etc. It is not a huge garden so it can be...

I discovered Halifax last summer and it became my new prefered city in Canada. It would be too long to explain why but one of the main reasons is this park (or gardens). It is a haven of peace and beauty. Fully matured gardens. Bring a book, take your time, use the many benches, relax.

While on a hop on-hop off bus tour, we visited the Public Gardens. The park is beautifully laid out, and we loved seeing the dahlia garden. Some of the flowers were huge......6 in in diameter. Some tiny little cotton balls. However, all we stunningly beautiful. This is not a large garden, but worth strolling through. We liked visiting this garden...

This center city Victorian style garden is a treasure! When we were there there was a special Dahlia exhibit that was spectacular. (we life next door to the also wonderful Brooklyn Botanical Garden) and the Dahlia exhibit was special. The lay out of the Halifax garden is lovely and an easy enough walk for folks of all ages. The bandstand...

all the work put into these gardens is amazing ..very beautiful. We walked from our hotel and all through the gardens. some of the trees were totally amazing and I wish I could have them in my yard. Talk about character!

The gardens are beautiful and the cafe is fantastic! We really enjoyed the relaxation of the gardens - right in the middle of downtown. It was a welcome retreat to visit and have lunch at the cafe too.

We wandered around here on a Sunday morning. It's free, with several entrances, and it's a lovely spot to escape for a little bit. Signage on the plants could be better for learning what grows in the area--it would be more useful for residents and more interesting for the rest of us. If my stay had been longer I would...
Beautiful horticulture. Just 10 to 15 minutes walk up the hill from downtown waterfront. Lots of chairs to sit down and relax.

What a wonderful find! Walk up the hill from the downtown cruise dock,through downtown, to the Public Gardens. It is a great place to just walk around and enjoy. We brought a snack and enjoyed a little rest on a few different benches as we progressed through the gardens. The fall Dahlia Display was spectacular. Colors and Shapes I have...
Fantastic public garden. Despite being late in the season-lots still in bloom. Paved way for those with impaired mobility. Near all of the usual Halifax sights.

The last week in September is off peak for these gardens, which feature a pond, bandstand, rose beds, annual beds, and impressive dahlias. It is easy to pair with a visit to the Citadel, but not worth planning your trip around.
A large, beautiful European formal garden in the center of town, easy walking from the Harbor (the walk there is very nice, too) flowers are stunning, water features beautiful!

We were told that there were three places not to miss: The Citadel, the Maritime Museum and the Public Gardens. Well I'd place the Museum first, then (on a dry day) the Gardens and then the Citadel. It's a pleasant stroll to and round the gardens - past the Citadel and the Barracks and along Spring Garden Road for some...

We truly enjoyed this beaurtiful 18 acre park in Halifax. It is beautifully groomed and has a large variety of different types of gardens. The Dahlia displays of BC cultivars is facinating. I understand why it used to be quite the thing to be seen strolling thru these gardens many years ago. Be sure to add this to your list...

This was the highlight of my visit. The Gardens are just lovely. The landscaping is beautiful and there is a quaint feel to them. The central bandstand is used for concerts sometimes (alas not on the day I visited) but it is a little oasis and well worth a visit.

We spent some time wandering the paths of the gardens. Lovely flowers, bushes, trees and ponds. The gardens are well maintained. It is a gem hidden in the centre of the city. Once you are inside you experience a quiet and peaceful atmosphere. I hadn't visited in some years and wondered if the damage from hurricane Juan was still evident,...

I imagine that you won't find a fat person in Halifax due to the sheer amount of walking and in some cases...scaling of the hills in that town. We visited the marina, then climbed up the san Francisco-like hill to the citadel.By the time we got to the garden, we were pooped and wishing someone would run and get...
Very beautiful park and so central to access. Loved the Dahlias! A great spot for tourists and residents. Worth a visit!

I enjoyed my time in the gardens. Really well cared for and nicely kept. I would have liked some more labels on what plants where what but even so it was a really restful place in a busy city. Nice benches and places to just sit and relax. The coffee house was also good. People there very helpful.
It was a pleasant walk amongst huge trees and sidewalks lined by bright flowers and a nice big pond in the middle. It is located just across from the Halifax Citadel.

I was happy to see that the Halifax Public Gardens wasn't too far from where I was staying when I was in Halifax. This park is a lovely oasis in the city. It isn't so big that you feel overwhelmed but it is big enough that you can have a nice walk or sit on one of the many benches....

So serene, a place to relax, take some beautiful pictures or just sit and visit. Lovely trees and flowers and water features. Also saw a couple getting their pictures made for save the date cards for the same date as my 44th wedding anniversary. It was a lovely day.
Nice variety of flowers & plants, with lovely walkways and ponds all around. Adorable coffee shop in the middle. A nice getaway from the city!

Beautifully manicured small park located in south downtown area. Waterfowl, flowers, unique trees, and many quiet walkways throughout the park. A word of caution for pet owners, you can not take your dog (even on a leash) into the park. No admission fee.
Nice job for a city park with free admission. It is quite peaceful, but still has areas for kids to play. Nice oasis in the city.

We walked through the Victorian Gardens on our way to the Citadel. They are very well laid out with beautiful flower beds, trees, fountains & a bandstand. We were surprised & delighted to hear the sound of bagpipes & hurried to see the lone piper
A wonderful collection of plants and trees that are a real inspiration for any keen gardener. A "must see" attraction for any visitor to Halifax and free too!
Nice coffee shop and lovely gardens to explore - only minutes from the hustle and bustle of town too. Regular bus services which drop you off outside the gardens.

A definite stop in Halifax... The gorgeous flowers and different trees are beautiful. Located just off Spring Garden Road, it's a great place to have a peaceful walk before hitting the Spring Garden Road shops. Take your camera!

We were taken to the Halifax Public Gardens as part of a Carnival Cruise tour. The garden is spectacular with many different kinds of flowers, shrubs and trees. It is immaculately kept. We walked from one end of the garden to the other taking pictures the entire way. Caution! Don't feed the ducks. There are signs telling you to not...
These "public" gardens show with pride of ownership.Incredible display of floral design. We sauntered around the grounds for more than 2 hrs. taking photos of masterful displays.
We walked through the gardens and were impressed with the beautiful blooming flowers, the mosaic living plant displays and the well manicured walking trails. It is free and well worth a walk- through
Beautiful walk, nice collection of Dahlias on display. It's a Victorian garden and filled with children and walkers and a lively vibe.
It was late summer and the gardens still had much to offer. Dhalias were lovely. This must be a great summer spot.

Beautiful gardens with many fountains. A leisure walk in a beautiful setting. It takes about 45 minutes to circle through the gravel paths. The park is flat, but the gravel paths might be a little difficult for stroller, but I saw many children walking with their parents.

This is a lovely Victorian garden with many paths for strolling and gorgeous combinations of flowers, trees, shrubs, and fountains. It reminded me a bit of Kensington Gardens in London. It's next to the Citadel, so it's easy to fit into your tour schedule. Not to be missed!

We visit every year, and every year it is different but beautiful. There are special treats, like concerts or dahlia season, but there is always something. It is perhaps the nicest and cleanest and best maintained city park I have ever been in. And just a short walk from the Citadel and from downtown Halifax.

These gardens are quite lovely, and worth wandering a half hour or so -- maybe more if you are into horticulture or want to sit on a bench and watch the ducks for a while. They're between the Citadel and the Spring Garden area, so they offer a nice place to sit and rest on a longer ramble. There's a...

Really lovely located in the middle of Halifax. Great layout with wonderful gardens. The flowers were beautiful and the presentations of the gardens worth seeing. There is a nice little ice cream place in the gardens where you can enjoy, coffee or ice cream. Really liked the blueberry.
An oasis of calm in a beautiful city. Well tended gardens free from litter. A safe place to relax in the summer sunshine with a cafe if you need refreshment.
So much history - loved the fact that many plants and trees are labelled. Right across the street from the Lord Nelson.

What a wonderful relaxing place! This public garden is meticulously and lovingly maintained.There is a calm and peaceful place to see many beautiful trees and flowers. There is lots of places to photograph the gardens. There is also a beautiful casual eatery, where you can buy food, ice cream and coffee. They also offer gifts, and mementos you can...

We stayed across the street at the Lord Nelson so we couldn't resist starting our day of seeing Halifx at the Public Gardens. It was a beautiful morning for a stroll and the gardens are absolutely lovely. We're glad we took the time to see them.

Beautiful wrought iron gates welcome you to a area of calm and beauty in the middle of the City. Numerous landscaped gardens, well maintained walking paths, flowing streams with water fowl, huge trees, etc.Just Gorgeous! You forget the noise and hustle of the City just feet away!

Lovely park which is always very well maintained. Very nice spot for a quiet break, as it is really surprising how quiet it is in the middle of the park. The grounds give me lots of inspiration for my garden, which unfortunately looks nothing like it! Definitely worth a visit!
Really nice gardens in the middle of town - excellent place to spend a couple of hours. Beautifully maintained

column3: City of Port-of-Spain, Port-of-Spain, Trinidad and Tobago
column4: Very well kept, gorgeous paths and sitting areas. Very friendly ducks! We were actually there into September, and the milder weather was lovely in this serene place.
Very nice to see. It doesn't take long to walk around. Lots of beautiful flowers hybrids I've never heard of. It's free too. It is what you make it. Have a picnic bring a blanket etc.

The public gardens is a beautiful place to visit. It is usually very calm and relaxing. It is open for everyone, free of charge which makes the place a must-go, specially considering it's proximity to he Citadel Hill and downtown Halifax.Keep in mind that, for obvious reasons, the garden only opens to the public during the warmer months.
It has nice flowers, and just a quiet place in the city, nothing exciting but a pond, ducks and gravel walking paths.
Visited the Public Garden on an overcast, drizzly day and was still impressed by the bucolic beauty.A very peaceful and calming venue. Well worth a visit...bring your camera!
The gardens are simply amazing, great flowers and the grounds are kept in perfect condition. It says a lot when on a sunny day there was 5 weddings going on!

No trip to Halifax is complete without a stroll through the Public Gardens. The family and disabled-friendly landscaping, eye-pleasing blooming ornamentals, and architecture recapture a Victorian sensibility you don't often see in North American cities. Easy to spend a day people and duck watching.
close for walking distance on top of the town, take the time to stroll the gardens and if lucky, take in a old time concert.

This 18 acre garden is a pleasant location for a stroll in the city. We had about an hour to kill before a dinner reservation - and we decided to walk through this garden.The trees are very old and well maintained. Labels on flowers and trees identify the unusual species that are located here.Several water fountains and a...
Interesting to see so many elderly local visitors, since it's centrally located and public transportation must be a popular place for locals

This is an absolute must while in Halifax. The grounds are kept immaculate and there is so much history that are part of the Public Gardens allure. There are many dedicated trees, shrubs and statues that are dated back to the beginning of Halifax as a city. We visited this site many times when we lived in Halifax in the...
This was my third time visiting public gardens. It is relaxing to see the beautiful flowers, fountains and greenery in the middle of the city, I visit these gardens every time I visit Halifax.

My sweetie & I visited during the 1st week of July. The rains made for a sloshy yet incredibly green walk about. So green, like the grass was plugged in! Each view was prettier then the next. My guess is that it's lovely year round and saw they have concerts/plays there sometimes which would be nice to see!
go to the fort afterwards- nice combo and very do-able in a morning. Nice flowers and states, fort has nice tour and in period costumes with cannon fire and marching bad, too.
Nice place to walk thru and sit awhile. There is even a building serving coffee and ice cream. Free concerts on Sunday.
Smaller than expected. Made for strolling and picture taking. No jogging p or bikes allowed. Beautiful gardens, flowers, ponds and gazebo

we took some great pictures here. Happened to stumble upon it and it was really nice. Generally not the type of people who are into flowers and stuff, but it was nice to walk through. If the weather was better, it would have been a great place for a picnic!

Walking distance uphill from the waterfront, this public park was a jewel in the city. There were flowers everywhere, a few fountains, a large pond, many flat terrain paths to explore and places to sit. Even a few ducks in a stream. Well set out, no through traffic or bikes and easy to walk. There was food available outside the...
It was a great tranquil place to visit to step out of the hustle of the crowds! The place was laid out so beautifully and well maintained. A great place to stroll and relax.

This is a beautiful public garden in Halifax NS. The ponds, flowers and trees are remarkable. It makes a nice quiet getaway spot for lunch or a rest from the city. If youa re travelling to the area figur abut an hour tio walk through. Seasonally there is a small coffee house type vendor that is open at the west...
I just love walking here. The flowers are always changing. Great people watching and tons of photo opportunities. It is very clean and safe.

On a vacation to Nova Scotia in August, I visited the gardens. As an avid gardener and lover of flowers, I was very impressed. I was amazed at the size of the gardens for a town the size of Halifax. The gardens are well laid out and there are benches on the paths in many areas and they are very...

What a beautiful park! Well manicured with a wonderful collection of plants and flowers. No bikes, no joggers, no dogs. Very peaceful. Take a stroll, read a book, have lunch, visit with friends and family. We grabbed breakfast & coffee from the nearby Tim Hortons and sat at one of the many benches and enjoyed the views. Thank you Halifax...
Take a stroll back in time in this beautiful park. Manicured lawns, flowers, a pond, a quaint bandstand. Definitely don't miss it.

Yes, the gardens are worth visiting, but after reading other reviews I was expecting more. Everything is indeed beautiful, it's just that... it's small, so small! We spent an hour as we had some free time before going back to the airport, but 20 minutes would be enough to spend there, unless you are very much into flowers and trees....
Fabulous, over-the-top fountains and superb planting make this a genuine Victorian style garden well worth visiting. Well tended and often informative signage. Good for all ages

This is a beautiful park located in the downtown area. I found it to be well maintained, it was large enough to enjoy a very long stroll. It's so nice to see a city with this much "green" in the downtown area. Take note of the front gates, they were purchased oversees at an action, they are beautiful.
Well worth a visit. Nice peaceful area in the middle of the city. There are plenty of seats to relax and just watch life go by. You can also get some nice icecream there!
If you are into Gardens, this is probably a nice stop. can easily be done by taxi if you come on a cruise, no need to spend money on a tour.
We had a very informative tour guide. This is definitely a stop for anyone interested in photography. The weather was great and so was our trip.
Nice to go for some peace and quiet. Flowers and trees are just beautiful. The gardens are kept very clean and well maintained.
The trees and shrubs are nicely layed out and you gain a sence of peace while strolling around.You even forget the main Spring Garden road traffic noise.
What a treasure in the middle of a city. Nice areas to walk and sit to relax and ponder.Such an area of pride
Fabulous surprises around each corner...peaceful...absolutely beautiful spots dor a walk....we went there twice!
Well worth visit. Impressive variety and tranquility in relatively small space. So glad I took time to go

I stopped in the public gardens and sat near the fountain for almost an hour listening to the water.This place is tranquil and a good spot to just take in the beauty of the flowers. you can also see the trees bent from the hurricane the hit Halifax years ago. Check out the band stand and patio of the restaurant.
These gardens never disappoint. There is always something beautiful in bloom. The dahlias are a highlight in August.
Amazing grounds and floral beds. A lovely spot to relax on a lazy afternoon in Halifax. What a gift!

This is a great spot in the center of the city. Lush lawn areas, and fantastic gardens to spend some relaxing time in. It nice to see the pride that the people take in the gardens and you will not be disappointed. By the way there is a little house there that you can get some ice cream from that...
These gardens are very well done and easily assessable. It is worth spending time walking through the park. Good option for photographs.
Nice respite in middle of city with benches and quiet areas. Not elaborate or monumental, just a good place for a break.
Nice park in centre of city, flowers could use a little tlc..but quiet peaceful atmosphere. Good history lesson. Great ice cream!

This is a very nice, well-maintained garden with a number of nice statues, water fountains, picturesque footbridge over water, and many floral and plant areas. It is quiet, with strategically placed benches to sit on and admire the views. Very relaxing.
I'm not sure if they've been caught yet but my little girl was almost tripped by a rat that ran out in front of her...in the middle of the day! Kind of gross! Beautiful park though, we visit weekly.

Either a short walk or a long stroll through these gardens will impress you. Such a beautiful well-planned garden! You'll enjoy something striking around each bend. Lovely place to spend some time -- & free.
Halifax public gardens is a wonderful respite from sightseeing or just to chill. Varieties of flora and fauna are breathtaking. Wonderfully kept.
I loved this garden because it was beautiful but I also liked it because so many of the plants were labeled. There is a little cafe in the center. It would be a nice place for a light breakfast
Easy walk from the waterfront. Nice way to see a city park and take a relaxing walk. Surprisingly nice cafe and gift shop.

Well worth spending a couple of hours here. It is a beautiful garden, well maintained, with benches, fountains, and lovely vistas. It's free, but you can leave a donation. A good place to rest your weary body, after serious sight-seeing.
Beautiful English style garden in downtown Halifax. It's a really nice place to wander, or sit and read. Really pretty in the spring and early summer when the flowers are in bloom.

After tromping up and down the hills of Halifax, the Public Gardens offered a lovely respite from the cement. It is a small area--it won't take more than 15 minutes to walk through it--but has a nice stream and some beautiful flowers, at least in August. As a special treat, there was a brass quintet playing when we were there.
Most beautiful landscaping. wide paths. Lots of shade and sun. Colors are great. Very relaxing and photogenic.

These gardens are right downtown and very convenient to reach. They have a lovely coffee/icecream shop inside along with a small gift store. We just enjoyed strolling in the garden, sitting on the benches, and sipping tea. Lovely way to spend the morning!

I have been going to Halifax Public Gardens since I was a little boy. The peace and calmness from this place is something I cannot describe. So many wonderful places just to sit and take in the beauty of nature! Read a book or people watch! Its up to you!

If you enjoy gardens, or are simply looking for a break from the bustle of Spring Garden Road, duck into the Gardens for an hour or so. These Victorian-era gardens are a Halifax icon and everyone from families to solo travellers will surely enjoy a taste of the beauty and tranquility they offer.

If you are looking for a lovely walk, and a good opportunity to snap some pictures of some truly lovely and unique flora then the Halifax Public Gardens are truly lovely. There are plenty of unique flowers here that I have never seen before, as well as many lovely trees.The park is rounded off well by a few very...
This is a must see when visiting Halifax. The gardens are absolutely beautiful. It is a historic site. Don't forget to see the swans. A stroll through the gardens will put you back in time.

We love walking through the paths of the Halifax Public Gardens,a few times a year.Towards the end of June,all the young people come here for Prom pictures...so much fun to watch. All summer,you have weddings taking place and people just coming for their wedding pictures.We love to grab a take-out lunch at Pete's Fruitique(very close,a wonderful market) and come...

Come visit our garden Oasis!!Lots of pretty flowers,birds,ducks,fountains and the beautiful grandstand.Lots of the high school kids get their Grad pictures taking here.It's free and sometimes they have concerts.A must see in Halifax!!

The Public Gardens is always clean and beautiful. The flower gardens are out of this world and so nicely maintained and kept. The paths are easy to get around by any age and with a wheelchair. There is a bathroom and canteen as well as lots of sitting areas. Theres a grandstand for musicals, a duck pond and geese. Been...

The "Gardens" are a beautiful oasis in the heart of Halifax. Beautifully landscaped, lots of benches to relax upon, an open field, lovely fountains, birds and ducks to delight everyone, a beautiful grandstand where FREE concerts are held and lots of shaded areas too.It's the best deal in town, the Gardens are free for anyone to use, they close...
Well maintained and a nice easy stroll through the park. They do have restrooms if you need them. A few ducksi f you are lucky
Lots of shady areas to sit and read or watch the work go by. Lot so flowers and a nice café in the middle with a big range of ice creams.

Lovely gardens to take a walk through, have a picnic or stop for an ice cream at the canteen. Take your lunch and enjoy your brown bag in the sunshine. Lots of places to sit both in sun and shade. Great spot for little kids to run about and see the ducks; and its free. The gardens are beautiful and...
Halifax public gardens are absolutely wonderful. They're in the heart of downtown and well worth a stroll. It's a great park, with lovely flowers and often hosts free concerts.Don't miss them!

Stunning trees, cute ducks, beautiful ponds with bridges, an elaborate water fountain, and colorful flowers galore. Located on one of the most central streets in halifax, Public Gardens is a must see. Grab some ice cream and go for a stroll. Visit the swans, sit on a bench and take a breather while people watching. If you're lucky you may...

The Halifax Public Gardens is a spectacular park in the heart of downtown Halifax, Nova Scotia. It covers 16 acres and boasts gorgeous walking paths amid a vast array of flowers and trees, a pond (full of ducks), numerous fountains, a bandstand (from where free concerts are offered every Sunday of the summer) and a coffee/ice cream shop. It's a...

Public Gardens is in the center of the city - close to one of the nicest streets of Halifax -Spring Garden Road. The gardens are well kept and is a nice quiet place to sit and take in the day and admire the many species of plants and flowers and trees. . Spring Garden Road offers shopping and a great...
Beautiful location for photos and just enjoying nature in the heart of the city. Lush gardens, duck ponds, Gazebo and seating to enjoy the scenery.

These gardens are well cared for, great variety of plants and flowers and are one of the best kept secrets in Halifax. And as others have noted its free - great place to decompress or to take an alfresco lunch. ( For fans of Keeping up appearances waterfowl provide the riparian entertainments lol!)

The Halifax Gardens are a wonderful experience in nature - various gardens in season and wonderful, relaxing strolls to be had by all. Bring your camera along to have memories of the beautiful vegetation you will see. Enjoy some paddled ice cream as you stroll the pathways or sit and watch a concert in the gazebo. A place for everyone...

The flowers are so pretty,the walk is great,its the best place to be,your right in the heart of downtown,so many things to see,alot of people get married here.photos are always so pretty,its a well kept park
Beautifully laid out and relaxing to sit there and watch the world go by. The flower beds were very colourful

July and August are great months to visit if you like color. The flowers are just so full of color. In an hour and a half visit, I captured 133 pictures. Just beautiful! A great place to take a book and relax in the fresh air. It's so beautiful and peaceful.

A beautiful place to spend an afternoon break from shopping and sightseeing in Downtown Halifax. The gardens are well maintained and very beautiful. There is often entertainment provided in the gazebo. There is a small store/canteen and places to see the ducks and elegant swans. A must see when visiting Halifax

It's been 10 years since Hurricane Juan battered Halifax and the Halifax Public Gardens. Mother nature has a way of restoring devastated areas to their natural beauty. In the case of the Public Gardens it has "come back" better than ever and is a welcome oasis in the midst of the city. With its beautiful trees and lovely flowers you...

The Public Gardens offer a refuge from daily chaos of noise and exposure. You'll find shade and simple beauty in the surroundings...and on occasion a concert or public tour. A lovely spot for an evening stroll... before dusk.

Victorian gardens developed in the mid-1800's.Many old trees decimated in 2003 by hurricane Juan so symmetry of plantings was lost.Lovely for a stroll any day.Information at http://www.halifaxpublicgardens.ca/Geese & ducks in artificial pond.Hotel and restaurants within the downtown area.Short walk (1/4 mi) to the Citadel fortressShort walk (1/2? mi) to the harbour front

It's pretty and it's free. Great place to relax, take pictures and you can't beat the price. It's right in the heart of the city, so it's a great place to check out. It's about a 10 min walk from the waterfront...almost all up hill, and by Citadel hill. It's seasonal though.

The Public Gardens are a great place to visit and to take respite from the hustle and bustle of the shopping area of Spring Garden Road. Generally very quiet, benches throughout the gardens,It is a lovely place to sit, grab a cup of coffee at one of the coffee shops on Spring Garden Road and just enjoy. Please put your...

Seventeen acres of Victorian gardens taking up a full city block in the heart of Halifax. The gardens are breathtaking and include fountains and statues that honour Queen Victoria and also war heroes, a duck pond, carpet beds, rose gardens, flower beds, and a beautiful bandstand which offers free concerts on summer Sunday afternoons. Stroll through these beautiful gardens or...
A very quiet, peaceful spot in the middle of the city. A great spot to admire the beautiful greenery or to people watch.
A visitor to Halifax should indeed visit one of North America's oldest Victorian gardens. It is what makes this city both a historical and visual gem. An oasis in the middle of the city.
Just a lovely, peaceful place to walk, run, or just relax. A "must do" if you are in Halifax for a day, a week or even if you live there. A great place to "stop and smell the roses".

Historic garden in the heart of downtown and the Spring Garden Rd area (shopping). In the summer there is often music played in the park. Great for a quick snack and a stroll around the gardens. Feed the ducks and a great play area if you have kids.

It is basically a garden in the heart of downtown. Sometimes you can catch a band playing music which is a bonus.It is not a place you would spend hours in but you can then stroll down Spring Garden Road and have a bite to eat and look at some of the shops along the way.If your really...
Flowers;ducks to feed; this truly is an urban oasis, with music on Sundays. It is one of the most picture perfect and serene gardens, I have ever sat it.
take a stroll, have an icecream cone and sit on a park bench and people watch or take a picnic to have in the grass. If its a Sunday there is usually a band taking place in the Grandstand.
this is a beautiful relaxing outing youcan get a ice cream listen to free concerts see the ducks and feed them a great day for a familytrip

its not needed as much as big cities that have no trees but its a beautiful park with beautiful flowers. they even have suga's there now were you can get delicious ice cream. definitely worth going for a stroll in to get a few pictures. its beautiful and relaxing
A beautiful and peaceful place to stroll in the centre of Halifax. Good washrooms and cafe on site. Shame it has a limited open season.

The Public Gardens are situated very close to the heart of downtown Halifax. Busy Spring Garden Road, with all it's hustle and bustle is right there and all the noise and hubbub just seem to stop when you push through the decorative wrought gates. There are many beautiful, meandering paths; colourful flowers, splashing fountains, swans, geese, ducks, shade trees. It...

A piece of paradise. Absolutely beautiful and free of charge. Perfect place for a picnic or a lovely stroll. My favorite place to pick up a picnic lunch is Indochine. The food is outstanding and the price reasonable. It is located very close to The Lord Nelson hotel.

The Halifax Public Gardens are a true treasure in the heart of the capital city of Nova Scotia. The exquisite work of the gardens personnel, having rebuilt and replanted much of the gardens after hurricane Juan, is on display, free of charge, for the world to come see and enjoy. Stroll amongst the various garden varieties, sit by the ponds...

If you want to escape the city without going far the gardens is the best place to do it. The beauty of the various flora offers the soul a bit of tranquility. Take a little lunch with you or grab some icecream and the little shack on site. Enjoy the fountains, ducks and statues. Take pictures with your companions or...

You can count on seeing a profusion of color from the time the gardens open in the spring untill late fall. Many of the trees are labelled with their variety names as well as many of the annuals and perennials. The gardens are especially well kept with knowledgeable staff. For me, the best time to visit is when the dahlias...
Love the gardens!!! Great place to sit & read or recharge after a visit tohospital or busy day shopping.

Many, many times I have gone to the Public Gardens just to enjoy the sun and relax. I don't know how many times that I lost track of time staring into nowhere , catching myself hours later and heading out very calm and ready for the rest of the day. What a wonderous place.

In the middle of the city of Halifax there is an island of tranquility and calm. The Public Gardens are beautiful walk in, sit down and have lunch in, and a great place to relax. The statues, fountains, ponds, and flower beds are very well maintained. This is a must see in Halifax.

The Public Gardens are absolutely beautiful. They are a short walk from downtown/waterfront Halifax and are a nice haven to sit and relax while touring the rest of the city. There is small cafe from which to buy treats and caffeinated drinks as well as plenty of benches throughout. If you're lucky there might be some live music going on...
Oldest Victorian gardens in North America. Beautifully maintained and a wonderful oasis in the centre of the city
Lovely afternoon in the gardens - music at the bandstand, the mayor and council passing out refreshments and cake. All and all, a wonderful day!

Lovely grounds, beautiful pond with ducks, bandstand which has a band playing every week, great coffee shop with sandwiches with ice cream which has been served for centuries. A must on the tour of Halifax
It's really worth going for a quiet stroll. Very peaceful although it is surrounded by busy roads. If you drive, parking could be a problem, but that's valid everywhere in Halifax.
Very nice out door activity for families to enjoy. A free afternoon outside enjoying the flowers, and each others company.

Don,t miss these gardens.They are absolutely beautiful in the summer.Beautiful flowers and statues and water fountains.Take a nice leisurely stroll in a very peaceful quiet part of a busy city.there are flush toilets and a bandstand where you can watch local bands singing.excellant get away

The Public Gardens are 16 acres of magnificent plants, statues, fountains, & walkways. This attraction has been here since the 1870s when many smaller gardens were consolidated. Even the main gate dates from the early 1900s. There are spacious recreational areas together with a large pond & a small stream. Ducks and swans wander through the grounds. People come here...

So much history in this place, one of only two Victorian gardens in Canada... complete with waterfowl/birds and wonderful flower gardens. However, be sure to check out the sculpture as you walk throughout. Barbara Delorey has a wonderful book: Three Centuries of Public Art, that describes the history in detail, along with fabulous photos.

The Public Gardens are right in the centre of the city and in walking distance of all the downtown hotels. It's a large, beautiful place where you can almost forget the hustle and bustle around you. On a hot day, head to the small house-type structure along the southern edge and get an ice-cream or cold drink.

A must-see when in Halifax. It is centrally located near plenty of shopping and close to downtown and an easy walking experience. It is a stunning and serene place to visit with plenty of beautiful garden displays and birds.

This is one of the most pretty places to visit in Halifax. The public gardens is very well kept and is full of flowers and trees. Great place to have wedding pictures or any pictures for that matter . Little bridges to cross with ducks and Swans,they have a band stand with noon time entertainment a must to see while...

These gardens are beautiful and a wonderful place to go and relax, walk, take picture and just generally enjoy the blooms and atmosphere. Also, from time to time there are band on the grandstand and a great snack bar with wonderful icecream.
These historic gardens are wonderful ... a tranquil oasis in the middle of the city. We strolled around, sat on the benches, watched children and ducks at play, and had a snack.

When you're in Halifax, Public Gardens is a must. Located on the prime shopping and eating district of Spring Garden Road, the Gardens are a peaceful and relaxing alternative to the busy street. You can wander the property and look at the many floral beds and beautiful restored fountains. A lovely coffee and ice cream shop will give you the...

This is a must see in the Halifax area. It was hard hit by hurricane Juan back in '02 but has made an amazing come back. There is beauty everywhere. Advisory: Do not feed the birds (ducks, geese, swans, etc.). You could be fined.

I have been to the Halifax Public Gardens many times. I love the beauty - flowers, trees, birds, ducks, etc. - but also the tranquility and it is a wonderful to sit, read, people watch and contemplate life.
Lots of good things to see if you are in that area of town. If you like the flower, duck geese this is good. Also a nice place to eat a sandwich for lunch.
serene and amazing all in one trip ~ an oasis in the center of the city ....color and shape surrounds the ponds and the wildlife .. A treat for all of your senses .
Even though I live in the city, I visit it a few times per year. it is a welcome break from the Downtown hustle and shopping.
This historic park in the centre of Halifax. it is safe and a favorite with children .It is well maintained. Lots of flowers and ducks.
A Halifax highlight. Beautiful flowers and music on Sundays. Park benches great for relaxing and reading.
Don't miss the public gardens if you're in Halifax. And don't forget to go to the refreshment stand, where they have terrific coffees and ice cream and baked goods.
Absolutely stunning place to visit. Plenty of plant displays, a very cute walk with a little cafe in the middle tool
Quiet and serene surrounding. It was so relaxing to take a 30 min. time out for a stroll in the midst of shopping. Even my 13 year old daughter enjoyed it - took photos with her IPad.
Directly across the street from our hotel, the Lord Nelson, these gardens offer access for walking and viewing lovely flowers, shrubs and landscapes based on the original Victorian design.
There was nothing to dislike. A lovely stroll around but nothing outstanding or particularly memorable. With so few sights in Halifax I would nonetheless recommend a visit.
Absolutely beautiful! I wish I could get my gardens to look like this! highly recommend taking a walk threw.

This is a lovely, well-maintained public garden with an interesting history. It's not extremely large, so it doesn't take a long time to see it all. There is a coffee shop inside the garden with baked goods, and also public wash rooms. There is no admission fee. At the end of July roses and day lilies were blooming. It would...
The Halifax public Gardens are only small and nothing exciting. Nevertheless I find them quite pretty and cute, perfect for a picnic. In summer they offer free concerts.
Beautiful place for a relaxing walk or go and read a book. A relaxing oasis in the middle of downtown.
After a great supper, our waiter suggested a walk in this park.Wow ...very well kept with beautiful plants and flowers;;;;;all this and for free.....amazing
If you want to go for a lovely walk in Halifax the gardens are great. Very pretty and relaxing. I'm glad I went.
It was hot, hot, hot on the day we visited Halifax, but the Public Gardens were cool and relaxing. Grab an ice cream and a bench for a break in touring.
This nicely manicured English-styled Garden was a lovely place to sit and while away a lovely warm afternoon.

It was late afternoon and the fog was rolling in while we visited. Nonetheless, my wife and I thoroughly enjoyed the visit to the Public Gardens. This is a true Victorian garden layout with lots of beautiful flowers and statues, but also intricate bed layouts.

We biked through Halifax, which was an excellent idea. This park was splendid. This is a formal garden. We got to see a tree that was planted by Queen Elizabeth. The flowers were in full bloom. The fountain was splashing. The fat, healthy, ducks swam in a big pond. The people were friendly and helped with picture taking.

A perfectly maintained garden, right in the heart of the downtown Halifax area! Grounds were lovely, with many convenient benches for contemplation and some beautiful statues and floral tributes. A must-see!
A great day to visit these lovely gardens. We enjoyed the symmetry of the flowers. Every area was very well-maintained. Plenty of benches to just sit and enjoy the view!

If you are in a crunch for time all you need is an hour or tops one hour and fifteen minutes to tour these fabulous gardens. We used roadside parking to park our car. Inside the gardens we were approached by an insanely happy well dressed man who was clicking photos of the garden who offered a flower to my...

..for a visit since the flowers had not yet bloomed and the trees lacked foliage. An example of a Victorian garden- this is probably best visited during the height of the flowering season to be truly appreciated. There were a few fountain but were not upland running at the time of the visit.

Truly a gem! We actually stumbled upon the Public Gardens and I'm so glad that we did. It's full of walking trails, benches and of course, over 2,000 kinds of flowers. It's beautiful and absolutely a "must see" when in Halifax.
I really like the relaxing atmosphere and the beautiful flowers... a great place to relax on the bench and watch the ducks or stroll through the flower gardens.
A big fan of the Gardens, love walking through from early spring until the fall. Walk around the twisting paths and enjoy the views from the many benches. A retreat in the heart of the city.

The Public Gardens is a great place to stroll when visiting. In the heart of town it is a very quite place to sit and unwind. You ca watch the ducks and admire the flowers or just relax with a coffee or ice cream. The sunday concerts are also very nice

The gardens have a large variety of plants and flowers, places to sit and relax and wide paths for walking. They also have concerts at certain times during the year. Unfortunately we were only there for a short time, but would come back to enjoy the relaxing atmosphere, easy accessibility and hopefully a concert some day.
If you have time, this is very much worth a visit. One of the best gardens I have seen in any city or town.
Just go, you won't regret it! Lots of animals, flowers, great paths and public washrooms too, if needed!

This victorian public garden is absolutely beautiful, a gem in the middle of the city. If you have time, it is a pleasant stroll. If you have limited time in Halifax, this might not be as high on the priority list.

It doesn't take long to walk though the Public Gardens and well worth the stop. There are beautiful well maintained flower beds, some Victorian sculptures and fountains, plus some nice public washrooms.
Worth the time to stop and wander around. Always something to see. Bring your camera if you like green and other colours of things that grow .

Fortunately for us, this garden was right across the street from The Lord Nelson Hotel where we were staying so was very easy for us to find. Had I realized that when checking in I might have thought to ask if there was a room with a view of the Garden available ... but I didn't. So, I settled for...
Band-stand, ponds, fountains, rose arches, winding pathways. Very relaxing to walk around or just sit and enjoy right in the heart of Halifax.

A lovely historical garden right in the heart of Halifax. My favourite garden beds were/are the 'serpentine' beds, and the most moving was the now large maple(?) tree planted by school children in the 1800's to the memory of a local army officer killed in Africa during service.The tea rooms are delightful.

These are English Style formal gardens. Complete with a cafe to have some tea (or ice cream...). Sit on a bench and watch the ducks or geese and just enjoy the afternoon. This is a great place to do it.
Have some ice-cream from the Sugah that is in the coffee shop in the middle of the gardens! I recommend Mint + Chocolate Fudge... Tasty!
Even on a dreary, rainy day, this was a delightful stroll displaying a well cared for park. It will not take long but is nice and offers some beautiful photo opportunities.

A wonderful break, just strolling around looking at trees and flowers and birds, and sometimes sitting on a park bench to watch the other strollers pass by. A few ponds and lots of greenery and paths. Across the street on one side is a large old cemetery, and quite close on the other side is The Citadel.

Very pretty for a walk through or hanging out. But, let it be known that you're supposed to stay off the grass except for designated areas (they were polite however, when asking me to move off the grass)

On our tour of the 10 sites of Halifax, the Gardens ranked in my top 3. The garden is full of beauitful flowers, well kept and easily a place you could stay for hours. We, unfortunately, only had about 1.5 hours but if you can stay longer, I highly suggest doing so. They ask people to be respectful and not...

Probably the best know gardens in Canada is the Butchart Gardens an hour or so out of Victoria BC. If you like gardens you should check out the Halifax Public Gardens. This is a smaller attraction to be sure but it doesn't involve a $50 cab ride as it is in town. The designers seem to have tried to have...

Beautiful, peaceful respite from the surrounding busy city. Lots of shade and benches to sit on while enjoying the flowers, trees, birds, lake and stream.Halifax lends itself to walking through much of the main downtown area. When you need a break from all that walking, this is just the answer.
The gardens are in the downtown area and are absolutely beautiful. The hard work of the gardening team is appreciated. Definitely worth walking through and enjoying.
Go if you like flowers. A nice diversion from just drinking and walking around. The flower presentations are attractive with quite a variety of plants.
Thoroughly enjoyed walking around these magnificent gardens. The variety of flowers, trees, and plants were stunning!
Investigate the Public Gardens if you want an easy stroll in the shopping and dining area of the city.
This was a lovely garden and interesting place to visit. It was a busy rainy day while I was there, but still worth the walk and time.

It was nice to visit the Public Gardens again this year. I remember going here as a child growing up in Nova Scotia.The Public Gardens are located right across the road from The Lord Nelson Hotel where we stayed on this visit.It was so nice to stroll through the gardens, sit on a bench and watch the ducks,...
Stopped at Uncommon Grounds first for a coffee and then spent 20 min wandering the park. Beautiful grounds, lots of people and even a few weddings having photos taken.

Average spot to walk through in a park-like setting in the middle of a city. Nothing spectacular here... plants and flowers and a few water birds with just as many pigeons. If looking for a park, should just go to a park.

The title says it all. It is FREE. It is very close to the QE II health center, for landmarks. There is a very nice ice cream shop at the entrance, and the flowers, tranquility is amazing. You can go through rhododendron bushes the size of your house (go through the bush) - my kids loved it. There are duck...

You can experience a quiet, calm environment for reading, walking or picnic with your family or friends.On Sunday (June-September), enjoy a band playing music under the roof (Sitting available).Ponds, ducks, trees and flowers to please you.
A large variety of plants. Historical features. Free admission. Good location because it is in the heart of the city so easy to drop by before or after a meal or shopping.
Not much there to see or do but perfect for a stroll with a coffee or maybe a picnic with the family or friends
Beautiful for a morning walk with anyone at all times of the day. The plants, trees, and flowers are exquisite

nice gardens in the city....but don't walk on the grass...they yell at you for that. Really a pretty public gardens with a variety of flowers and trees. Was there Sunday and they had a band in the bandstand playing old music...very relaxing.

This is such a beautiful spot. It is hard to believe that it is located in downtown Halifax in such a busy spot. When you are in here you wouldn't even know it. Well maintained and lush; a great place just to relax and enjoy nature.

If you are at all in to gardens or flowers this place is for you. It's one of the best (if not the best) Victorian gardens around. A great to relax or take a short stroll. The gardens aren't too large, but when you are in them you lose all the hustle and bustle of the city. Well worth the...
Always enjoy my walks through this pretty and historic park.Pretty trees and flowers and interesting gravel paths.Love the updated fountain.

So pretty and peaceful, even on a crap weather day! Beautifully kept grounds with lots of trees, flowers, paths, birds, a bridge, a fountain, very very beautiful. A definitely must see, even if its only for 10 minutes if you're strapped for time. I would have loved to come back to have a picnic there. Also conveniently located in downtown...
Beautifully kept and lots of hidden corners - really worth a visit. the rhodedendrons were a joy to behold.

This park is great! You can walk around it, you can pic-nic on the tables, you can bring chess pieces and play (the chess board is included on the table!), you can look at the beautiful flowers and the little pond, there's also a lot of different birds! You can listen to an orchestra outside if you like classical music,...

They were beautiful. We simply loved the gardens. it was raining hard but we were undeterred! A must during your visit to Halifax. Right across from the Lord Nelson Hotel and very convenient for visitors.
Strolling the Public Gardens was so relaxing. The beautiful flowers and little bridges were so nicely arranged throughout the park. What a nice place to spend time in, in the heart of the city.

We visited a few days ago the Annapolis Royal gardens, they are nice, but the Public garden in Halifax is sublime! Exellent maintained, and a great variety of threes, shrubs & flowers. A must see if you visit Halifax!

The Halifax Public Garden, across from the Lord Nelson Hotel, was established in the 19 th century on the typical model of a Victorian Garden. Covering a large city block it has numerous walkways, trees, flowering shrubs, and floral displays. There is also a stream, pond and bandstand. No sports, jogging, or bicycles are permitted so it is a pleasant...

The public gardens is a wonderful place in the centre of the city to stroll and look at the flowers and the beautiful landscaping. You can sit around the bandstand in the middle of the gardens and just relax and watch all the people.The staff do a great job with all the flowers throughout the gardens.

Right in the city centre, the Public garden encompass a whole huge block. Lovely to stroll through and enjoy this oasis of beauty and calm after a busy day or to start your day with some space and nature.
It was a nice little park situated nicely in the downtown core. The grass was too wet when we went for a picnic but would have been nice.

As a home gardener I always try to visit public gardens when I travel. This is a beautiful garden with a small lake (and a miniature Titanic). There were specialty gardens, bridges, decorated lamp posts, a gazebo and much more. Allow about 2 hours so you can relax and really enjoy this spot.
A lovely formal garden with lots of spots to rest and enjoy. Not a park to play touch football or throw a frisbee.
Very beautiful park. Very colorful in the summer and fall months. Definitely a must see when visiting Halifax.

The Public Gardens are not to be missed. We were there the end of May and they were changing out the spring flower beds to summer. Duck pond, paths, landscape plan, pavilion and more. What a delightful place!

I love the beautiful blossoms and greenery! It's such a nice walk through even if you are heading somewhere else. It's a great place to meet friends , bring children, or enjoy on your own. I had most of my wedding photo's taken here and am so pleased with the results!!

This park is a great escape from buildings, pavement, and people. The gardens are both on land and in the water. Beautiful flowers, well-kept paths and benches. I saw many using this garden as a pass thru, which must add some serenity to the day. A great place to take a book or just contemplate nature. Well done!

What a treat! A lush park tucked away in the city centre. Full of bloom and light, shadowy nooks for reading or strolling. A nice way to spend a leisurely afternoon. A must-go-to spot for out-of-towners to rest their feet after a busy day shopping on Spring Garden. Pack a picnic, bring the family, stroll the paved walks, photograph the...

This is lovely place to visit in the spring while in Halifax! Popular with the natives (!), it is joyful surprise for the tourist! The winding walks and lovely stream wending its way through the Gardens make a quiet respite from the busy streets surrounding you.

This would be a beautiful spot in downtown Halifax when the garden is in full bloom. Unfortunately it was still too early for all the flowers. A nice relaxing spot to take pictures, read a book or have a snack at the little cafe.
A nice place to get away from it all in very beautiful surroundings. It changes with the seasons and is very pleasant to walk around or sit and contemplate.
Lovely garden space in the middle of downtown Halifax! We were a bit too early in the spring, so if you go, make it end of May. The cafe there had awesome food too!
The Public Garden is a wonderful oasis of calm in the middle of the town. Pavilions, flowers, trees and lawns invite you to relax and distract from the town.

Wonderful seeing it from the window of hotel. It is surrounded by a high attractive metal fence which you can see through. There are wonderful trees and flowers and being spring, it was all quite attractive.

I grew up near Halifax and this is one of my favorite places to stroll. It is a beautiful oasis in the heart of the city. The landscaping is wonderful and you can walk laps around the perimeter all afternoon if you like. There are no bikes so it is very leisurely.

If you want to take some time out and enjoy a quiet moment or two and the smell of all the beautiful flowers, this is the place. Halifax Public Gardens is in the center of the city and a wonderful place to just sit back and enjoy some quiet, along with the bird song and ducks.

Great Park. Visit the cemeteries all around the area. They are like parks as well, and very old. The churches are also old and have great architecture. An Anglican one on Tower Rd, and the Catholic one on Spring Garden are good to visit. All in walking distance.Point Pleasant Park requires a bicycle, taxi or rental car, but is...

As a return from away, I miss the country. I spend many lunch breaks walking through the gardens to destress, refocus and clear my head. Every day I see something new and wonderful about nature whether it is new growth, a visceral representation of the marks of the season I'm in, or the truly exotic plants that a professional can...
great detour on the way to Spring Garden for shopping. Flowers were just blooming and it was beautiful! Great location to take young kids.

spend some time looking into each corner of this lovely garden. my favorite was a bench under a willow(?) tree by a small pond that had friendly ducks as its inhabitants.the gardens close around dusk, so give yourself an hour or so to enjoy. :)

The Halifax Public Gardens are the best example of a Victorian garden in North America. Situated in the centre of downtown Halifax, it is an oasis where you can escape the bustle of city life and go back to the grace and elegance of Victorian times. There are frequent musical presentations, ducks and other waterfowl, beautiful paths surrounded by flowers...

Open all summer long from dawn to dusk and free! This top attraction in the heart of Halifax is surrounded by a bustling city and you hardly notice the city noise when inside. Beautiful Victorian gardens surrounded by huge trees, duck ponds, fountains and raised flowerbeds. There are paths for wandering through the 18 acre grounds as well as a...

No better place to rest, kill time, meet up, read a book or explore the beautiful gardens. Kids love to stop in for ice cream in the summer. Right across from the Lord Nelson Hotel and near Spring Garden Road shopping.

Since my daughter was 3 years old she has loved going to public gardens. Seeing the ducks, lakes, statues and so much more. So many pretty flowers and a beautiful view. Definitely a place worth visiting while in Halifax.

It's a public garden with a long history. It's pretty and worth spending a few relaxing moments enjoying. The weather hasn't been especially kind to the public gardens, especially Hurricane Juan, but that doesn't diminish the quiet ambiance of this public park.

A stroll not only in June, but from May til November, while the gardens is open.................the smell of the flowers, the grass, iso green, friendly folks walking by say "Hi", or sit, relax in serenity. We are so fortunate to have a little "Peace of Heaven" right in our city, no need to travel...........can walk there at lunch for all...

A wonderful place to sit back in the shade. My partner and I like to grab some food from Pete's and have picnic on the lawn.I'd also suggest checking out the geese. Sometimes we stay at the Atlantica, and always stroll through the garden on our way back from downtown.

Not to be missed. They are one of the best reasons to live in Halifax. It is one of the few remaining Victorian public gardens in the world. I've cut through the gardens on my way to work every day that its open for over thirty years and have never tired of its beauty.
Beautiful gardens in the middle of the city. Lovely flowers and mature trees. Nice coffee shop with patio to enjoy the views. Excellent way to spend a couple hours in the summer!

in late summer, the flowers are still in full bloom and this grassy, green and peaceful park ( or garden) is a rare treat in a busy city centre like Halifax. There is lots to see and enjoy as you stroll the grounds ( Mrs. Robinson), and great opportunities to get some great photos of the flora! Lots of cool...

Halifax Public Gardens are a must-see...the gardens are magnificent. It was a bit of a dreary day when we visited, however, we still enjoyed every every bit of it. Great way to spend a few hours. We highly recommend visiting the gardens. The gardens are located very close to the Citadel.

This gated garden setting in the heart of Halifax is a true gem. From the beautiful colors, fragrant flowery aromas and bobbing fowl, it is a nice centrally located escape from the humdrum of downtown.

These gardens are down the street from the Citadel. They are free and are excellent for a nice, peaceful stroll to get away from the downtown hustle and bustle. They are not real large, but not real small either.

This was a clean garden which is well maintained and worth walking through. We went as part of a city bus tour and most of Halifax has a Scottish origin as can be seen by the kilts most tourist bus guides wear. Our guide got the bus to drop us off so we could walk through the gardens and then...
Wonderful place to visit. Be sure to go. Even in the rain it was beautiful. Lovely pond WITH boats, what fun.

We visited the public gardens in mid-October and found them still in really good shape considering it was the end of the season. This is an absolute gem in the heart of Halifax. The park is free! There were lots of little things to look at and take in. It is a great park for photography.
Old Victorian floral park with a lovely bandstand, ducks, running water and lovely trees. A peaceful spot to sit and enjoy lunch from one of the many nearby sandwich shops.

No trip to Halifax is complete without a leisurely stroll through the Public Gardens. Open from spring until late fall, the gardens is a quiet oasis in the heart of the Spring Garden Rd. shopping district. Take and hour or the day and enjoy the peaceful surroundings. Maybe even catch a free concert at the bandstand on Sunday afternoon.

Beautiful public gardens in Halifax, very nice formal gardens that gives an idea of what Victorian era garden looks like formal flower beds, pavilions, grassy areas, roses, etc. A relaxing stroll. Little cafe in the middle of the park is surprisingly nice.

Lovely and diverse park to stroll through and enjoy the sights. The varied gardens display beautiful foliage groupings and different settings through the park and along winding pathways. Open areas hold grassy pastures where parent lay on blankets with children and people toss frizbees and footballs. Many benches where people are sitting and watching or eating their lunches. Lovely ducks...

This is a wonderfully maintained small park. One would not really wish it to be any larger than it is as this fact, in itself, would detract from its elemental charm. (This is not Central Park.) A must visit site ..... and on a very regular basis.
This small public space is well worth some relaxing time while in Halifax. There was a band playing on Sunday afternoon when we first visited, and it was a most pleasant experience.

If you live in the city you tend to take a stroll on a regular basis through this little jem in the middle of the city. It is well laid out and beautiul through the seasons. Well worth the trip if you are in town.
beautifull victorian garden in the heart of hallifax, daily summer concerts, great place to walk, or relax. close to everything.

I walk through on my way to or from an appointment, or if I have time to kill when in Halifax. It is clean, well kept, always beautiful with foliage and flowers year round. Lots of birds, and often entertainment. It is Halifax's mini Central Park.

I had not visited the Gardens in several years and the growth and care is amazing. The amount of work put into this is substantial and certainly worth the visit. Take your time, a lunch with the family and stroll through one of the most beautiful gardens in Halifax

We went on Mother's Day and it was so gorgeous and we were surrounded by other families. I strongly recommend doing it for that occasion. We've been a few times before but in the Spring it truly is special.
Sun was out, temperature was hot, amazing for that time of year.... flowers everywhere. Just like summer.

We love Halifax - we came from a huge city so find Halifax relaxing and easy, so are never looking to escape it whilst there.Whether like us you just felt like a wander in the park or you need to escape the city - the Gardens are he perfect place to be.Beautifully tendered and lovely walks, in summer...

A stroll through the Public Gardens is always relaxing - no matter what time of year. It is just off Spring Garden Road and Robie St so it is in the heart of Halifax and easy to access. The gardeners have always answered my questions about plants, music at the bandstand is enjoyable, and lunch on a bench in the...

What a lovely garden this is. Right in the heart of the city but so peaceful. In the heat of the summer the many trees provide cool shade and the good number of seats provide lots of tranquil spots to rest from shopping or sight seeing. There is often music in the bandstand and many city workers go there to...

It is amazing that the city just seems to fade away when you walk through the gates.... this spot is worthy of many visits throughout the Spring, Summer and Fall (it closes for the winter)...... each day there is something else in bloom..... take time to see the roses!
If you like gardens this is a place that is eay to stroll thru with a great variety of plant material well maintained and laid out. It is close to downtown and a good place for a picnic.

At the centre of old Halifax the venerable Public Gardens unfold. It is a rich Victorian themed park with formal flowerbeds and a lovely old bandstand (performances every summer Sunday!). Tours are led by a bag-piper each morning - we residents enjoy it as our backyard.

A lovely April walk in this Park just as May was approaching. Well marked historic trees one planted by King George VI, different types of plants, shrubs and trees well marked. Great place for photos. Wildlife abundant in the ponds. Not commercialized. A not to miss place while visiting Halifax.
The weather was exceptionally warm during our stay which made for perfect walking conditions. There were so many people taking in the quiet serenity of the park and its surroundings. Very nice place

Breathtaking at all times of the year. Flowers carefully tended, huge trees, sculptures and fountains, often a band in the bandstand, and lovely ice cream and coffee. Great for people watching and reading while slurping something cold or hot.
What a lovely spot to take a stroll sit down and gaze on beautiful floers beds, ducks swimming in the pond. orperhaps hear a concert at the Bandshell.Beautiful restored Victorian fountains.
peaceful bliss in a busy city. So nice to have an area like this so you can still experience what nature can offer. Everyone seemed to just alot slower and njoyig their surroundings,
A pretty walk through the park right in the middle of downtown. Incredibly colourful. If you park along the street nearby, careful you don't lose track of time!
There was so much beautiful foliage in this park. I could have stayed for a couple of hours. It was just spectacular!

This large section of land is conveniently placed in the main area of the city. We passed through on our way from the port to the Citadel. There are nice fountains and statues but the most eye-catching decoration is a scale model of the Titanic floating in the pond. Kind of gives you a shiver. The large central gazebo is...

Took the Hop on, Hop off bus in Halifax for a morning drive to the gardens. At first it was cool,then as we walked about the sun came through keeping us warm. The Asters in these gardens were outstandingly beautiful. Some were on bushes that were 4 - 5 ft. tall. The amazing colors of these blossoms were intriguing...

The Gardens are a wonderful place to walk or sit just to enjoy the surroundings. Each season brings its own colourful display and of course in the spring, you might even spy a few duckings in the Pond. The newly created main gate offers easier access and the Tea Room is a pleasant spot to enjoy an icecream with grandchildren...
Also yummy ice cream in the cafe in the middle of the gardens but they tend to have short hours. Check for the ducks in the pond.
Just beyond words. Everyone must visit. A local fav. for wedding and grad pics. Located in the Spring garden Rd. area, so many restaurants, so many shops, near hospitals and universities.

it,s a relaxing walk anytime of the year, i have always been delighted any time i have gone through the gardens.there are so many beautiful trees and flowers to see all with info to tell you what they are and where the trees came from. the bandstand is also nice to see when the band is playing.the baby geese are...

This Garden is just wonderful from opening to close (approx April to December). The flowers through the seasons, the ducks at the pond, the tall trees, what a magical place at the heart of a superb city.
The park covers a whole city block or two, close to other attractions and had lots to offer for a windy November afternoon.

Even if you don't like formal gardens, this one is beautifully planned and beautifully planted. The only drawback is that the little cafe in the gardens can get overwhelmed in peak season, especially when a bus tour arrives.

Actually we live across the street from the Gardens, very quiet place with beautiful landscape grounds. You can choose from different paths and spend quality time. Perfect for a romantic walk, seniors or parents with young kids.Classic spot for prom picture.
This park is a must see in Halifax. There is nothing to dislike. Such a wonderful and peaceful park.

This is a beautiful public park! There were AMAZING Dahlia's of all shapes, colors and sizes! There is also a fountain, a small duck pond, a WW1 Statue and plenty of places to just relax and enjoy the beauty!
Different times of the year offer all different flowers, entertainment and wildlife. Easy to walk, or use a wheelchair even. Plenty of places to sit on grass or benches. Nice place for a picnic!
A wonderful place to visit in the center of the city. The flower gardens were beautiful, the layout serine, and overall just a nice place to visit and take pictures.

We walked through this lovely park on a nice summer's day. Beautifully kept and wonderful arrangements of all types of plants and flowers. It has four different entrances from all for corners of the square. It's free. It's a peaceful way to escape the city sounds without leaving.

Gorgeous public garden. Right in the middle of Halifax, but the trees block out the sound of the traffic.Some winter beds, and some evergreens. Of course it is more lovely in the summer months, but a nice walk in the fall as well.I don't believe it is pen year round.

This place always brings back memories of childhood.Born and raised in Halifax, yet as an adult I never go.I really should. Such a beautiful spot!I miss feeding the ducks and walking around with an ice cream.Very peaceful there.Excellent spot to get wedding or graduation photos.
It is a surprise to see such a nice park with so many well cared for flowers in the middle of town. If it is larger it will even be better.
Very pretty gardens, nicely maintained. A great place for a walk or picnic . The shop sells snacks and beverages, and there are a few tables out on the deck.

These were a delight. Usually a walk through a public park is not the most pressing of destinations when you are not long in a place but these gardens have to be an exception. We caught some of the last flowerings of the summer and the turning of the leaves for the Fall. Are visit up the New England and...

The "Gardens" are a Victorian heritage, harkening back to a simpler time and friendlier society. Trees and flowers from all over the "Empire", migratory birds, free concerts and all in the middle of the most peaceful garden in a thousand miles!
Great place to walk around and relax and enjoy the beautiful gardens. I went in October so there was some foliage there. Very nice. Definetly a top attraction in Halifax.

Unfortunately we were there after the season. But still we could see some of the garden's beauty. Water flowed through it and there was gardens in the shape of a snake, a garden that honored the Queens Diamond Julibee, and some of the roses were still blooming. Wish I could see it in spring or summer...
Even though we went in October, there were plenty of beautiful flowers to see. It's a formal English garden in the middle of Halifax.

This is a wonderful place even if you don't like flowers. It's beautiful and spacious and well signed. Washrooms are clean, there is a concession selling food and drinks (although not cheap, $2.69 for a small San Pellegrino), and lots to see. Ponds, bridges, gazebo, nice walking paths. In late October, the dahlias were still blooming and they are magnificent....
I walked through the park after visiting the Citadel. I really enjoyed the Victorian garden, and it has a unique layout and feel to it. I visiited in fall, but it was very spectacular even then.

I was here in middle of May Victoria Day long weekend for my brother's wedding in town. Being from Ontario and never having been east of Montreal before, I had no idea what to expect.Considering that it rained for 5 days before and 5 days after the wedding day, the sun coming through for the WHOLE DAY of the...
Great place to have visiting grandchildrens' photos taken. Flowers were beautiful . Very peaceful spot.
These are just great.well laid out and looked after, with a little river running througheven have our Queens Jubilee in flowersa must to visit

And free. Not large but a nice oasis in the city. Easy to walk around and view all the different gardens. When we were there, the dahlias were in bloom and were fabulous. Could do without the silly Titanic model in the pond though.
